safePlants.name: Pawpaw
safePlants.description: The pawpaw tree has smooth gray bark, but becomes scaly overtime. Pawpaws grow in clusters that resemble bananas, are high in vitamin C and healthy fats, and can be eaten raw. They flourish from August through October.
safePlants.location: All counties except in high elevations.

safePlants.name: Dandelion
safePlants.description: With long pointy leaves, and bright yellowish orange flowers, this planted is sought after as an addition to salads or for tea. It is Abundant in vitamin A, vitamin C, and vitamin K. As well as being known for maintaining good vision and immune function. They flourish from May to October.

safePlants.name: Wood Sorrel
safePlants.description: Growing up to 10 inches tall, this heart-shaped leafleted, tiny yellow flowered, plant is a wonderful zesty treat. It is high an vitamin C and can help with nausea, fever, indigestion, and swelling. They flourish from mid-June to mid-July.

safePlants.name: Morels
safePlants.description: This small and unique mushroom is a highly sought after ingredient for many dishes. With a hollow stem and cap, this fungi is great for it's anti-oxidative abilities, anti-inflammation, and gut health preservation. While it is edible, it must be cooked before eaten. They flourish from April through May.
safePlants.location: More prevalent in high elevation counties

safePlants.name: Serviceberries
safePlants.description: The tree that these berries grow on can be found while hiking, or even around your neighborhood library. With smooth, gray bark, star-shaped white flowers,and small red berries, this sweet treat is sought after as a healthy snack or added to sweet treats. It is great to have on hand for it's notable iron amounts. They flourish in late June or July.

safePlants.name: Ramps
safePlants.description: This wild onion has broad and smooth, light green leaves that can grow to be 8 inches long. They have a strong garlicky-onion flavor and can be eaten raw. They are known for being delicious, as well as their anti-bacterial and antiviral qualities. They flourish from March to early May.

safePlants.name: Elderberries
safePlants.description: This delicious berry grows in the form of a clump-like shrub that ranges from 8 to 10 feet high. Only being edible once cooked, it is rich in vitamins, minerals and antioxidant compounds, while having anti-inflammatory and antibacterial properties. They flourish from August through September.

deadlyPlants.name: Pokeweed
deadlyPlants.description: 6-10 ft tall, pokeweed bushes have tiny pinkish white flowers that turn into penny sized black berries. Mashed berries stain anything a reddish/purple color. Symptoms of root consumption include: burning sensation in the mouth and throat, nausea, vomiting, a weakened pulse, drowsiness and impaired vision precede death in extreme cases.

deadlyPlants.name: Rhododendron
deadlyPlants.description: Growing up to 40 ft tall, this plant has dark green leaves, which are different shades on either side, surrounding clusters of 10-12 small white or pink flowers. Symptoms of leaf or honey consumption include hallucinations, diarrhea and death in severe cases.
deadlyPlants.location: Every county, but more prone to mountainous regions

deadlyPlants.name: Holly
deadlyPlants.description: Standing at 10-20 ft tall with small red berries matched with small and pointy dark green leaves, these bushes are perfect for the holiday season, but not for any stew. Symptoms of berry consumption include: vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration
deadlyPlants.location: Fayette, Grant, Greenbrier, Hardy, Mercer, Monongalia, Nicholas, Pendleton, Pocahontas, Preston , Raleigh , Randolph , Summers, Tucker, and Webster.

deadlyPlants.name: Jimsonweed
deadlyPlants.description: Ranging from 3-5 ft tall with thick purple stems and large, white to purple flowers, this plant is part of the nightshade family. Symptoms of petal or nectar consumption include: rapid pulse and breathing, dilated pupils, restlessness, nervousness, muscular twitching, diarrhea, depression and weight loss. In severe cases, it is fatal.

deadlyPlants.name: Common Moonseed
deadlyPlants.description: Growing upwards of 20 ft, in a spiral fashion around trees, this vine and it's fruit are very similar to grapes. Every part of this plant is toxic and can inhibit muscle movement, as well as be fatal in severe cases.

deadlyPlants.name: Bulbous Buttercup
deadlyPlants.description: Ranging in height from 6-12 inches, this flower brings back joyous childhood memories of. While not being listed as lethal to humans, it is still not safe to consume. If chewed, blisters would appear on the lips an face.. If swallowed, the symptoms are abdominal pain, diarrhea and vomiting, dizziness and even paralysis.

deadlyPlants.name: American Yew
deadlyPlants.description: Growing from 3-5 feet tall, this shrub is toxic from the roots to the needles. Ingestion of any part of this plant can cause an altered mental status, blue-colored lips, breathing difficulty, Coma, convulsions, Diarrhea, dizziness and enlarged pupils.

messages.text: Anyone else see the disclaimer for the West Virginia Mushroom Club?...

parks.name: Kanawha State Forest
parks.description: Located seven miles south of the capital city of Charleston, Kanawha State Forest is an outdoor lover's haven. It is known for its extensive network of hiking and biking trails and has some of the state's most popular picnic areas
